bug.short_desc: Error parser - cannot generate proper marker for file outside of the workspace

long_desc.thetext:
If you get an error or warning in a system include file (which typically reside outside of the workspace directory) then you can't give a file reference to the marker. The result is that the user cannot double click on the problem and be taken to the location in the editor.
ErrorParserManager has a couple of utility functions to get an IFile for you from a path but unless the path resides in the workspace it won't work. Even if the error parser implemetor creates an IFile resource for the file and passes it to generateMarker it still doesn't work. In this case nothing is shown in the problems view at all. I think there is probably an exception being thrown.

You can only create markers on IResources. Since the external files aren't IResources, you simply can't do this.
But it is a good requirement that needs a solution. Hopefully someone will think of something innovative and come up with one.

Here is something innovative:
- If the error parser cannot create an IFile object for a given path then it attaches the problem marker to the project. That's why the file cannot be opened in a simple way from the problems view - A new marker type could be defined which has an additional attribute like "externalLocation" (derived from the standard C/C++ problem marker) - The error parser could be made to use the the new type, still use the project as resource but store the original path of the error in the marker's externalLocation attribute - An popup menu object contribution for the new marker type could be created, as an analogy of the Delete C/C++ Marker contribution which allows manually deleting C/C++ Markers. The new contribution would say: "Open External File". An action would be provided to open the external file in an editor and place the cursor in the appropriate position.
The main drawback of this is the fact that the user must know or guess that while double-clicking does not work, he can still get the file opened via a popup menu action. I would have liked to somehow override the default double-click action for the Problems view but I could not figure out how to do this. The current action which is caused by the double-click is hard-coded into the ProblemView class and it's framework
Another drawback is that annotiations probably also won't work for the external file. I'll have to think about this some more, maybe we can configure the CEditors annotation access ...
Anyway I would like opinions on whether this is worth doing in spite of the drawbacks, or whether other, more elegant ways of doing this can be imagined.

(In reply to comment #2) > - A new marker type could be defined which has an additional attribute like > "externalLocation" (derived from the standard C/C++ problem marker) I think this could be applied to any text marker.
> Another drawback is that annotiations probably also won't work for the external > file. I'll have to think about this some more, maybe we can configure the > CEditors annotation access ... > Anyway I would like opinions on whether this is worth doing in spite of the > drawbacks, or whether other, more elegant ways of doing this can be imagined.
Have you looked at ExternalSearchAnnotationModel and DebugMarkerAnnotationModel? They try to solve the same thing, kind of. ExternalSearchAnnotationModel does not provide any annotations for markers currently, but can be quite easily changed to do so. The drawback is that it is only used when the file is opened with ExternEditorInput and ExternalSearchEditor. DebugMarkerAnnotationModel supports breakpoints only, but works generically for all editor inputs and editors. I think we need a common solution for any marker type and any editor input/editor, otherwise it depends on the way a file is opened whether it will show problem markers or breakpoints - but not both.

Created an attachment (id=49345) This patch introduces the new marker type and the action to open the editor
Submitting an initial patch to create a sketch of a solution. What this patch does:
- Define a new marker type - Change the error parser infrastructure so that markers of this type, including the external location, are generated - An action contribution to open an editor for the external location
Second thoughts about this implementation:
- Perhaps a new marker type is not required. We could just define the org.eclipse.cdt.core.problem marker to always have the externalLocation attribute. In many cases this attribute would simply not be set.
Known defects:
- my new externalProblem markers don't have the "Delete C/C++ Marker" popup menu item which is contributed for the standard problem marker. I thought that by setting the super element type to org.eclipse.cdt.core.problem the menu item would be inherited. Any ideas? - The IMarkerGenerator interface must be extended by another method signature. Currently to my knowledge only classes in org.eclipse.cdt.core.tests get broken. Should I go to more trouble to avoid breaking things? Or is the extension of the interface ok? - The way the editor is opened and directed to the correct line is done without much internal knowledge.
Items to be done:
- Make sure that the ExternalSearchEditor gets opened. - Modify marker support so that the problem markers for the external file are also displayed.

Created an attachment (id=49600) Do the marker definitions and also support marker annotation display in external editor
This patch does all the patch before did plus adding an OpenExternalProblemAction which opens the ExternalSearchEditor for the referenced location. By a little tweak to the ExternalSearchAnnotationModel the markers are now being displayed in the correct place even in the external editor.
Design considerations:
- Decide whether a new marker type is necessary, or a new attribute for the "normal" CDT problemMarker is sufficient - Is it OK to reuse the ExternalSearchEditor for displaying problem markers? (I think it is) - Review and clean-up the implementation - Provide unit tests - Create a new bugzilla which will depend on #155379 and will be resolved when the external editor is opened upon double-click. In this way this current bug can be resolved and we don't forget that for external markers opening the external editor should ideally be triggered from a double-click and not from an extra context menu entry. - Create a nice icon for the action (suggestions, anybody?)
I'd love to have opinions on my suggested implementation.

(In reply to comment #5) > By a little tweak to the ExternalSearchAnnotationModel the > markers are now being displayed in the correct place even in the external > editor. The annotation model should filter the markers according to the file location, otherwise it would include markers for all external files associated with the same resource (#isAcceptable). I would also vote for reusing the existing marker type(s).

Created an attachment (id=53293) Reworked implementation which filters by location
The implementation has been sleeping (maturing, of course) for two months now. I have reworked it to suit the following requirements:
- I am reusing the standard C/C++ marker type and it has an additional attribute which is filled only for problems on external files. - The annotation model does filter by location now which is necessary because markers for multiple files are all stuck on to the containing project. (isAcceptable() implementation)
I tried to use existing JUnits to verify that my implementation does not break any existing things but found it was pretty confusing. Numerous tests from the org.eclipse.cdt.core.tests fail, also from tests which are related to external error parsing, such as GCCErrorParserTests. These tests are not in the nightly build test suite so I have no idea whether they should work or not. Btw I also tried in a different workspace to run them with the HEAD from the repository unmodified and they fail even under such circumstances.
I felt that the IMarkerGenerator interface was a little clumsy with it's long parameter lists, and I worked up a suggestion to make the ErrorParserManager.Problem class public and top-level under the more descriptive name ProblemMarkerInfo, and to use this wrapper object in the IMarkerGenerator.addMarker() interface. I am leaving the old version in place, but have marked it as deprecated.
For the implementation of the filtering in ExternalSearchAnnotationModel.isAcceptable() I had to get information about the project and external location path of the markers into the annotation model. I did it by extending the ExternalFileEditorInput, introducing among others a new constructor. I am confident that it will still be working correctly also in the old contexts, but it would be good to hear some comments from somebody who knows his way around here (Anton?)
So, here is the suggested patch, any more comments or opinions?

Looks good to me, just some comments on the ExternalSearchAnnotationModel: - The attribute for the external location is defined different in the plugin.xml (don't know if this attribute declaration has any effect at all). - isAcceptable allows only C problem markers. Rather, I'd suggest to not filter the type. This allows to use the mechanism for other marker types, too (e.g. breakpoints). - retrieveMarkers should not findMarkers with DEPTH_INFINITE, because we don't want to get all markers of all resources inside a project. - The model does not listen to resource changes, ie. it does not update itself if eg. a marker is deleted. Actually, I think we can base the annotation model on the ResourceMarkerAnnotationModel which handles this already. - One last point ;-) The ExternalEditorInput could be a little bit smarter and guess the marker resource from the ITranslationUnit (ie. the IProject it is associated with), thus the markers also appear when the input has been created without explicit marker resource, but there still remains the problem that a file opened with an IStorage only, will not show the problem markers. As a workaround, one could get all markers from the workspace root with DEPTH_ONE to cover all projects...

Anton, thanks for your fast reply. Mine is not so fast.
> - The attribute for the external location is defined different in the > plugin.xml (don't know if this attribute declaration has any effect at all). I changed this. The declaration may be important for the persistence of the marker. Even though attributes can apparently created and read without being declared the persistence mechanism may depend on the declarations. I did not try this, however.
> - isAcceptable allows only C problem markers. Rather, I'd suggest to not filter > the type. This allows to use the mechanism for other marker types, too (e.g. > breakpoints). Right. Filtering by the existence of the externalLocation attribute is strict enough.
> - retrieveMarkers should not findMarkers with DEPTH_INFINITE, because we don't > want to get all markers of all resources inside a project. Sure. DEPTH_ZERO is perfectly enough.
> - The model does not listen to resource changes, ie. it does not update itself > if eg. a marker is deleted. Actually, I think we can base the annotation model > on the ResourceMarkerAnnotationModel which handles this already. OK, I changed this too. Made the implementation of the ExternalSearchAnnotationModel smaller and cleaner.
I have two new concerns:
- Will the original external search stuff still be displayed correctly after my changes. Markers from external search will not have the externalLocation attribute set. They should be filtered out. How can I test this? - I have now figured out how to create a translation unit from an external include file's path and how to open the C editor on the file. This is even better that the external editor because now the outline also is alive. The drawback at the moment is that I need to fiddle with another marker annotation model (the C editor's) and have not yet figured out where to start. (Attempts with the TranslationUnitAnnotationModel did not succeed ...) A few pointers would be greatly appreciated.
I'll post the updated patch shortly ...

Created an attachment (id=53779) This patch has learned how to open the C editor
This patch can open the C editor on external files which have error markers. It does not yet display the markers in the editor as annotations. I'll have to do some more research for this ...

(In reply to comment #9) > I have two new concerns: > - Will the original external search stuff still be displayed correctly after my > changes. Markers from external search will not have the externalLocation > attribute set. They should be filtered out. How can I test this?
Search does not set markers anymore, instead the search adds annotations dynamically when an editor is opened, therefore this is not influenced by the change.
> - I have now figured out how to create a translation unit from an external > include file's path and how to open the C editor on the file. This is even > better that the external editor because now the outline also is alive. The > drawback at the moment is that I need to fiddle with another marker annotation > model (the C editor's) and have not yet figured out where to start. (Attempts > with the TranslationUnitAnnotationModel did not succeed ...) A few pointers > would be greatly appreciated.
I have committed a change to CDocumentProvider which uses the ExternalSearchAnnotationModel as fallback model. Thus the markers for external files are also shown in the CEDitor (I had to comment out part of the change as it depends on your patch).

(In reply to comment #11) > I have committed a change to CDocumentProvider which uses the > ExternalSearchAnnotationModel as fallback model. Thus the markers for external > files are also shown in the CEDitor (I had to comment out part of the change as > it depends on your patch).
Works great. I'll attach the patch including your changes for documentation purposes and commit it now.
Thanks a lot, Anton!

Created an attachment (id=54151) Patch with modified CDokumentProvider as suggested by Anton Leherbauer
The patch in the form in which I'll commit it.
Patch applied, hope I'm not stepping on anyone's toes ...

Thanks for the fix. I've been hooking it up with our builder and errors parsers and it's working great. One problem I noticed though is when you open problems in source files that are external to the workspace, they are not opened as source files (no c icon in editor tab). The reason appears to be that CoreModel#createTranslationUnitFrom only looks at includes (IIncludeReference's).
I guess this is sort of outside of the scope of this particular bug so maybe I should log a new one for it?

(In reply to comment #15) > I guess this is sort of outside of the scope of this particular bug so maybe I > should log a new one for it?
Warren,
since this bug is now long closed, and your problem is a trifle different, I'd prefer if you'd open a new one.
Thx,
Norbert

bug.short_desc: [hotbug] Option to generated wrapped WSDL

long_desc.thetext: We had a discussion with Richard Mah, he agreed that if an user wishes to create a WSDL with the wrapped pattern, an option should be available.

We believe the default should always be to generate the doc-literal wrapped pattern (when the user selects doc-literal). We have a few bugs where we sometimes don't generate this pattern. So would you find it acceptable if we simply hide the wrapped/unwrapped option in the wizard and only support the 'wrapped' generation pattern?

Hi Craig,
I have gathered some feedbacks on the question you post and sent you an email. Another question we have is whether this change can be made in WTP 1.5.1.
Regards,
Kelvin

Affiliation: IBM
Release you want this bug to be fixed in: WTP 1.5.1
Justification: Being able to generate wrapped WSDL is important especially for creating the .NET interoperatable WSDL.
Hot bug request accepted.

bug.short_desc: JavaFacetUtils.scheduleFullBuild(...) should use a more optimistic scheduling rule

long_desc.thetext: The org.eclipse.jst.common.project.facet.JavaFacetUtils class has a method call scheduleFullBuild(...), which does a full build against a project, and uses the workspace root as the scheduling rule. Instead of using the workspace root as the scheduling rule, the project should be used instead.

I chased down what JDT does in this situation. They call ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRuleFactory().buildRule() to get the appropriate rule to run the build job with. I thought, great it must be some sort of clever mechanism that only grabs as much as necessary, but when I looked at the implementation, the buildRule() method simply returns the IWorkspaceRoot. It appears that in order to do any build (even if it is a build of one project), the entire workspace must be locked. I will go ahead and change the JavaFacetUtils code to use the buildRule() method so that if it becomes more optimal in the future we will pickup the changes, but there will not be any user-visible changes for now.
Released the change described in Comment #1 into the 1.5.1 and 2.0 code streams.
Verified
Close.

bug.short_desc: Incorrect IProgressMonitor handling in AbstractCLaunchDelegate

long_desc.thetext:
The IProgressMonitor passed into AbstractCLaunchDeleate.preLaunchCheck(), buildForLaunch(), and finalLaunchCheck() is not handled according to the contract specified in the following white paper:
http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-Progress-Monitors/article.html
and thus suffers from some of the problems mentioned in the paper, like incorrect work counts and multiple beginTask()/done() pairs on the same monitor. The latter is particularly problematic for me because I am trying to provide a command-line launch command which must be synchronous to support scripting.
I have a proposed fix which I will post once I have reviewed it here.
Created an attachment (id=47367) proposed fix
Didn't apply the exact patch, but used the content and committed the changes to HEAD branch.

bug.short_desc: Import Config: Existing processes in library only are not removed by import

long_desc.thetext:
1. export a config, 2. create a CP 3. re-import the exported file 4. check that the newly created CP still exists
This is an existing bug, not a regression
Checked with Jinhua: this behavor is as desgined. Only old elements (leaf nodes) under package get deleted. Old non-leaf nodes (such as a CP) don't get deleted after import.
verified, closed.

bug.short_desc: The package template in the notation plugin is not up to date

long_desc.thetext: The package template (the java jet file to the EPackageImpl) inside the notation plugin is not out dated, it shoudl be kept up to date with the template in the EMF
This is important change and it is not risky ; i think it should be fixed in 1.0.1 the fix is ready on my machine
Anthony agreed this should be a 1.0.1 fix, changing the target milesetone to 1.0.1
fixed

bug.short_desc: [Sync View] Synch resource, override and update, resource already exists

long_desc.thetext: I have a file .project in my project. I have a .project file in my cvs repository, I choose synch with repository and it shows the .project file as incoming. I rclick and choose override and update and I am given a dialog that says "overwrite local changes?" I choose yes and then I get an error saying "A Resource already exists on disk"

I20060725-0800
I wasn't able to reproduce your case. Here's what I did:
1. Checked in a copy of org.eclipse.ftp into my local cvs server
2. With a new workspace, I checked out two versions of org.eclipse.ftp (named org.eclipse.ftp and org.eclipse.ftp2)
3. Modified the .project file in org.eclipse.ftp and committed it
4. Selected org.eclipse.ftp2 and chose Team>Synchronize with Repository; have 1 incomign change (.project file)
4. Right click on the project and chose "Override and Update" (I also tried just selecting the .project file)
5. Prompted to Overwrite local changes->Yes->changes updated properly.
From your description, it seems what might have happened is that your workspace might have gotten out of sync with what's on disk. That message will pop up if you already have a .project file on disk, but doesn't show up in the navigator. Try doing a refresh on the project and things should work. Please reopen this bug with further details if this doesn't address your problem. Thanks!

What you say is correct. I believe the resource was out of synch.
I think the workflow in this case is incorrect, if you choose overwrite local with incoming then it should overwrite independent of whether the resource has changed without eclipse realizing it, after all you did choose "overwrite".
If that is inconsistent with eclipse practices then perhaps changing the error message to indicate the true problem "that the resource is out of synch with the workspace" is the best solution.
I think the best place to start would be to improve the error message. However, we probably won't have time to look at this for 3.3.

bug.short_desc: ResourceException in buffer.save()
javaStream load results in message creation error

long_desc.thetext:
I reconfigured the tests, and was able to create this error in the tests, but I got it while loading the stream, not while trying to use a message.
I updated the stream, and now everything works again.
Everything is committed now, please try again. I'm a little skeptical that I've fixed the same problem though.

Right. This was a lovely bug. It's some issue in the 1.4 object serialization. Sondra and I were running with the same code but different jre's and it bugged differently. Always worked under jre 5.
Fixed by replacing that piece of code entirely. I believe that this will fix all the related issues

bug.short_desc: [actions] Format should not stop on read-only files, it should skip instead.

long_desc.thetext:
If I only have a few files checked out, when I try to format all the source code in my project, the formatter stops, since it detects some of my files being read-only.
It should not halt at read-only files, instead it should just skip them and only format the writable files.
It would provide better usability, as it will do as much as possible, which in this case is exactly what I want.
Note, this issue is not related to the following bugs 27207, 69193, and 121552 that want to format the read-only files. I do not want that!
verified in 20060807-2000

bug.short_desc: [UI] No help for extension schema editor

Google shows a link to help from 3.0, but not 3.1 or 3.2. In the 3.2 help topics, the Tools/Editors section of the PDE Guide shows nothing on the schema editor; nor do I see anything under JDT nor Platform.

Created an attachment (id=70740) Patch for bug 151025.

Whoops. Ignore that patch. That's the last time I keep all my bugs in one browser window. :)
Extension Point Schema Editor documentation will be available in 3.3

Extension Point Schema Editor documentation completely re-written and available for 3.3.
Target: Final 3.3 release.

bug.short_desc: Processes: Inconsistency in displaying ADD for contributing activities.

long_desc.thetext: Steps: 1.In a CP, create an activity and sub-activies: CP1 A1 t1 (associated with role and WP descriptors) A1.1 t1.1 ( this is associated with role and WP descriptors) 2.Let A1 contribute to another activity in a different CP. 3.Check browsing, ADD for A1 is not there. BUT ADD for A1.1 is displayed.

From peter's email about the same defect: (from peter) I created a pattern with two activities contributing to two different activities in OpenUP. Both activities had the same task descriptor. When I looked at the activities then in browsing mode I saw the new task in both places in the WBS. Excellent.
But here is the gap: It did publish an activity detail diagram, but without the new tasks. The requirements state that it does not publish any activity diagrams, but what about the activity detail diagrams? Because ADDs can be automatically generated and layouted. is it possible to create these with the contributed task? If this is not possible then it should rather not display an ADD at all (better than an ADD that misses the contributed TDs)
Fixed.
verified in M5-N20060818-1730
verified, closed.

bug.short_desc: Conflict state on tasks should be outgoing.

long_desc.thetext: When a task with outgoing changes is synced and the user chooses not to overwrite changes the task currently is placed in a CONFLICT state. In reality the new contents are downloaded and the users new comment is simply appended to this new task data. For this reason the state should just returned to OUTGOING.
IF this change is to happen we should probably have it in 0.9 to try out.
This is related to bug#163484.
Too big of change at this point to make 1.0, pushing post 1.0.

bug.short_desc: WSDLvalidator does not properly handle inline schema namespaces w

long_desc.thetext:
The WSDL validator does not properly handle inline schemas defined with namespaces that contain no scheme. More precisely, it is the import of other inline namespaces with no scheme that cause the problem. I've attached a WSDL document that reproduces this problem.
Curiously, this problem only seems to manifest itself when the schema namespace is specified as the default namespace, as in
<schema xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"...>
Created an attachment (id=46492) Sample WSDL document that shows the problem error message
And the problem is the WSDL validator incorrectly flags the import of schemas with a namespace with no schema with an error stating that the schema can not be located.
Targetting to 1.5.1.

The problem was with the inline schema generator. The generator was trying to be too smart and appending (incorrectly) the namespace as the schema location for inline schemas with no namespace prefix (such as xsd) and an inline schema import element. I've removed the offending code and added a unit test for this scenario.
Fix released to 1.5.1 and 2.0 streams.
Verified on WTP R-1.5.1-200609230508.
Closing bug.

attachment.desc: Sample WSDL document that shows the problem error message

bug.short_desc: Create a Delivery Process name with "&" is faulty

long_desc.thetext:
OS: Windows XP with SP2 Language: English Build: epf-composer-1.0-M4-N20060718-win32.zip
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new Method Library. 2. Create a new Method Plug-in 3. Create a new Method Configurations, click File->Close all to save this configuration 4. Create a new Delivery Process named "Test&Test", and select a Method Configurations, press OK 5. Delivery Process created. --->Problem: The Delivery Process name is shown as a shortcut key, an underline with a character
Expected Result: The Delivery Process name should be shown as user inputted
Remarks: 1. The same problem on RHEL4U3(en_US.UTF-8) 2. When we delete the Delivery Process named with "&", the same problem occurs on some others interfaces 3. The invalid character for Delivery Process name is [/\;*?"<>|] 4. The screen image is attached.

Created an attachment (id=46494) Defect behavior
View this image to see this BUG
This is not content related. Reassigned to tool component.

This is the limitation from Eclipse Label class which is trimming the "&" from method element name. Current behavior is : "Test&Test" displayed as "TestTest" "Test&&Test" displayed as "Test&Test" "Test&&&&Test" displayed as "Test&&Test" In fact '&' on Method Element name may lead several issues on publishing ( i.e URLs will be inactive with '&' on element name ). Considering all of these, we have decided to restrict '&' from name and from now onwards and error will be prompted if the user uses '&'.
Thanks, ~Lokanath Jagga

Due to the limitation of "&" usage on Eclipse Label class, we are restricting "&" on Method Element Name. Where are we do not do any validation on Presentation Name, users can use the same to specify if there is any "&" char on the name.
Patch has been applied on 03/12/2007, 5.30 PM PST. Pls verify the same on appropriate build. ~Lokanath Jagga
Fix is verified on EPF 1.2 20070314-1900 build. The element restrict using '&' as name. Close this bug.

bug.short_desc: [j2ee] lib & var EAR references classpaths failing

long_desc.thetext:
In WTP 1.0 J2EE utility projects and other dependent libraries, where automatically added to a EJB project's build path, when added as dependency to that EJB project. This was quite a nice feature, because build path and J2EE dependencies could be created in one go.
Now in 1.5 with the introduction of the EAR libraries build library the above feature has disappeared. Only EJB client (view) projects are added to the EAR libaries build path, but normal jar file (J2EE) dependencies, and not even J2EE utility jar files are added to the EAR libaries any more. Not only is this very combersom (one has to edit J2EE dependencies and build path separately), but it also will make developers not use the J2EE dependencies mechanism correctly, and just edit the build path - resulting in incorrect manifest classpath references.
So my conclusion is: normal jar references and J2EE utility references should also be added to the EAR libary build path.

Hi Jason,
This may just be a misunderstanding of the "derived" classpath settings from MANIFEST... Can you look into it?

I suspect this is a duplicate of 147758 The EAR Libraries classpath container should be exported; if it is not exported on your workspace, then this is a duplicate; try grabbing the newest 1.5.1 build.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 147758 ***

Trying to verfiy this bug with WTP 1.5.1 27 Jul 2006.
What do you mean by "EAR Libraries classpath container should be exported"? You mean as entry in the .classpath file?
Anyway - although J2EE utility projects are now listed in the build path "EAR Libraries", normal jar files still are not. The jar file is listed in the ear <project-modules> descriptor as module:/classpath/var/... Shouldn't it also be listed in the same way in the ejb project's <project-modules> descriptor?

Is this your scenario?
You have an EAR with a project module of any type (could be any a Utility EJB, AppClient, RAR or WAR). The EAR references a jar file in one of the following 3 ways: 1 as jar from the workspace, 2 as an external jar, or 3 as an extended variable. Then if you reference the jar from your project module it isn't added to the classpath.
Here are the 3 examples (which all fail) from my .settings\org.eclipse.wst.common.component file of EAR project:
<dependent-module deploy-path="/" handle="module:/classpath/lib/BankRA/connectorModule/BankAdapter.jar"> <dependency-type>uses</dependency-type> </dependent-module> <dependent-module archiveName="lib/D:/temp/BarTestClient.jar.jar" deploy-path="/" handle="module:/classpath/lib/D:/temp/BarTestClient.jar"> <dependency-type>uses</dependency-type> </dependent-module> <dependent-module deploy-path="/" handle="module:/classpath/var/JUNIT_HOME/junit.jar"> <dependency-type>uses</dependency-type> </dependent-module>
Exactly. In my case the jar file added to the ear is added by "module:/classpath/var". But as in your case the "lib" reference types fail as well.
Thanks for confirming the clarifiction; there was some confusion on my part before. The EAR Libraries classpath container for the dependent projects should be picking these up. It currently isn't. :(

Just an additional thought. We are working on creating ant scripts for building wtp projects automatically based on the wtp metadata. For that reason it would be nice if if also jar file references would be listed in the <project-modules> descriptor (and not only in manifest files) ... just a thought.

The manifest is the only place we will be listing the dependencies. We ran into problems in the past trying to keep all the meta-data in synch with each other. Things get especially tricky when the multiple meta-datas defining dependencies becomes out of synch (e.g. from forces outside the workbench). So, we decided to make the manifest the one and only authority for project dependencies because that's how it will work at runtime.
code checked into head; it should be in this weeks integration build for verification.
closing.

You probably have 'Completion inserts' instead of 'Completion overwrites' in your preferences. Please reopen if I'm wrong.

bug.short_desc: Refactor the SQLParser API to make it thread safe

long_desc.thetext:
Move state management code out of SQLParser
Currently many state maintenance code specific to the parsed document is defined in SQLParser itself, such as getScope ( Returns the scope constant at the current position, which is used by content assist to retrieve database meta objects proposals ), getReferencedTables ( Returns referenced tables in the parsed sql statement ). Therere potential threading issues here: the API cant make sure the return value and the corresponding sql statement always match. All these APIs should be moved from the singleton SQLParser to ParsingResult.
Postponed to 1.0
Done.
closed.

bug.short_desc: Unable to use two versions of the same plugin at design time

long_desc.thetext:
I'm developing two versions of the same plugin at the same time: A1 and A2. Also A1 depends on another plugin B1 and A2 depends on the same plugin, but a latter version: B2.
When I have all four plugins open at the same time in Eclipse 3.2, it seems that the classpath entries overlap and conflict. I have to close A1 and B1 if I want to work on A2 and B2, or the other way around.
I have other dependencies on those plugins, and I've specified some version constraints in my plugins dependencies. Unfortunately, those constraints seem to be ignored at design time.
The temporary hack suggested in the newsgroup is to change the plugin ID: this works. But it's definitely a hack IMHO.
It there a solution to this problem? If not, could this be directly supported in the future?
Moving to PDE-UI team.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 44512 ***

public final class SimpleParametersTest { ... }
is huge and contains public and private methods, classes and a public interface. I right-clicked on the class-name and selected "Refactor-Extract supertype", ticked "Use extracted superclass where possible" and chose only to include the interface in the extracted superclass.
The interface was moved, but the extracted superclass also contained ALL OTHER code from the subclass, thus duplicating it. The only difference I found was a protected in-line class that was made private in the superclass.
Best regards, Henrik

bug.short_desc: [performance] Improve efficiency of SystemView.recursiveFindAllRemoteItemFilterReferences()

long_desc.thetext:
In case of a Property Change event, SystemView.recursiveFindAllRemoteItemFilterReferences() iterates over all hosts even if the subsystem that's affected by the resource change is already known.
The search should be limited to only those hosts / subsystems that are affected.
Not sure we should really attack this for 2.0.1 -- Dave what do you think, could the performance improvement be measurable?
Bulk update target milestone 2.0.1 -> 3.0

bug.short_desc: Content assist and syntax highlighting don't work on WML JSP page with JSP Editor

long_desc.thetext:
Content assist and syntax highlighting don't work on WML JSP with JSP Editor Steps: 1. create a WML file whose extension is .jsp, containing the following content: --- content of the file --- <%@ page language="java" contentType="text/vnd.wap.wml; charset=ISO-8859-1"%>

Place content here.

 --- end of content --- 2. open the file with JSP Editor >> No content assist >> No syntax highlighting Addition: When I create .html and .wml files, content assist and syntax highlighting works with HTML Editor. Plugin version(org.eclipse.jst.jsp.{core,ui}): 1.1.0.v200606191945
Looks like StructuredTextPartitionerForJSP needs to recognize that a contentType of "text/vnd.wap.wml" means using the StructuredTextPartitionerForHTML
Created an attachment (id=47487) org.eclipse.jst.jsp.core.patch
Fix released for 1.5.1 & head.
closing

bug.short_desc: Move a used Delivery Process to another Process cause an error

long_desc.thetext:
OS: Windows XP with SP2 Language: English Build: epf-composer-1.0-M4-N20060718-win32
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new Method Library 2. Create a new Method Configurations 3. Create a new Method Plug-in 4. Create another new Method Plug-in, click File->Close all to save all items 5. Create a new Delivery Process belong to Plug-in A 6. Right click on it, press Move 7. Select Delivery Process of Plug-in B as target 8. Click OK. -->Problem: An error window popup with "Error during move"
Expected Result: The Delivery Process should be moved correctly.
Remarks: 1. The same problem on RHEL4U3(en_US.UTF-8) 2. This is the details error info:
Error saving file(s) org.eclipse.epf.persistence.MultiFileIOException: Resource is out of synch and needs to be reloaded: D:\TempWS\plugin1\plugin.xmi at org.eclipse.epf.persistence.MultiFileSaveUtil.checkOutOfSynch(MultiFileSaveUtil.java:453) at org.eclipse.epf.persistence.MethodLibraryPersister$FailSafePersister.adjustLocation(MethodLibraryPersister.java:634) at org.eclipse.epf.library.edit.command.MethodElementAddCommand$MoveOperation.save(MethodElementAddCommand.java:1768) at org.eclipse.epf.library.edit.command.MethodElementAddCommand$MoveOperation.access$3(MethodElementAddCommand.java:1751) at org.eclipse.epf.library.edit.command.MethodElementAddCommand$4.run(MethodElementAddCommand.java:1537) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:113)
Last modified timestamp for newly created plugin is not set and this triggered false alarm about "out of synch"
Verified on build epf-composer-1.0-M4-N20060719-1630-win32, this defect is fixed. Thanks.

bug.short_desc: Parallelizing JDT/Core

long_desc.thetext: ZRH got a couple of new laptop which have a dual core processor. Running Eclipse on such a hardware in most cases makes only use of one processor core (the task manager only shows 50% CPU). To fully leverage the power of these machine things like compiling or searching could be parallelized meaning that for compile we compile several independent files in || or for search we do the match resolving in parallel threads.
The issue will be with securing access to binding cache which isn't thread safe. The unit process queue is not far from a working queue already.

Resolving this issue to parallelise a lot of internal functions of Eclipse will become mandatory in the very near future. Intel have already demonstrated a prototype of a 80 core CPU and within 5 years they expect it to come to the general marketplace. So it is in the interest of the Eclipse community to have as many important internal functions of Eclipse to work with multithreading. Already quadcore Intel CPUs are available now.
I'm wondering why it is not a duplicate of bug 126121?

bug.short_desc: ItemPropertyDescriptor.getHelpContextIds should return null not an empty string array

long_desc.thetext:
Ed Merks suggested I submit this bug:
From: Ed Merks <merks@xxxxxxxxxx> Date: Tue, 18 Jul 2006 16:52:16 -0400 Newsgroups: eclipse.tools.emf
Keith,
It seems to me that what we return should be handled properly as not specifying any help IDs, but since I can't tell the history of what's all changed in the Eclipse APIs since we coded to them way back when, I'm fine with changing our method to return null now. If you open a bugzilla we'll fix it. As a workaround, you can override the createItemPropertyDescriptor in your generated item providers to return a derived ItemPropertyDescriptor that returns null for this method.
Keith Harrison-Broninski wrote:
Generate a template EMF editor, create an object, select it in the Properties view, then press F1. If you have the Error Log open you will see an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
The problem seems to be that org.eclipse.emf.edit.provider.ItemPropertyDescriptor has this method:
public Object getHelpContextIds(Object object) { return new String [] {}; }
which appears to be deprecated - it should return either null or a single String, preferably "org.eclipse.ui.property_sheet_page_help_context" - which would allow the standard context-sensitive help for the Properties View to be displayed. Returning an empty array the causes a crash in the help listener created automatically by the ExtendedPropertySheetPage.
Is there a workaround for this?
I display the Error Log in my application and don't really want users seeing an exception on pressing something as innocent as F1 :-(
Keith

IPropertyDescriptor.getHelpContextIds() no longer allows arrays of multiple contexts, so to keep up, our default should be null.
The fix is in CVS.

bug.short_desc: "Export jar" could also deploy jars from dependant projects

long_desc.thetext:
I have a situation where we package jar files (with source files in a zipfile) in seperate projects, to have both final static libraries and be able to see them.
Now we have a situation where I want to deploy such a project which utilizes a _lot_ of projects with exported jar-files. The "Export Jar" command only recognizes _compiled_ output and not exported jar files, making it less useful for us.
I therefore suggest the following enhancement:
* Exported jars from selected projects should be able to be copied to the same directory as the generated jar file transparently. A checkbox? * It should be able to generate a class path line in the manifest which contains the above mentioned jar files placed in the same directory.
I expect this to be a very valuable addition for the "multiple-jar" project which is not embedded in an application server or with a custom classloader.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 83258 ***

bug.short_desc: Please re-introduce a tree view for the schema editor

long_desc.thetext: In the previous version of web tools, the whole schema could be displayed as a tree. In the new version I can only see the subnodes of the currently selected node. I would like to see the whole schema structure in one view, like it was possible in the previous version.

I voted for this because I was deeply disappointed at the removal of this feature for 1.5. I guess I don't understand the removal of something so helpful to visualizing the schema (in terms of how an XML instance would look) - this type of view is why XMLSpy is so popular and useful. Perhaps it's not as technically correct, but it does allow one to more quickly understand the schema as a whole, by allowing the user to browse the schema in an instance-focused way.
Please bring it back, at least as another optional view.
*** Bug 172170 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I voted for this as well and would like to say that I completely agree with Dallas Vaughan.
Replacing the current view with the original treeview might meet objection, but I don't see why the treeview shouldn't be available as an optional view. What harm would that do? The treeview code already exists anyway so it shouldn't be a great deal of work to bring this feature back again.
I liked the treeview a lot and was very disappointed when I realized it had been replaced and I cannot help but add that I'm unable to understand how this change could be carried out in the first place. To my mind, if asked whether they wanted the treeview out, 100 out of 100 XML developers would say that they insisted on this view. It's deprecation is just about as baffling to me as if a UML plugin vendor had replaced it's graphical UML views with advertisements for crayons.
*** Bug 185217 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Outside Eclipse deleted files are not shown in Synchronize View

long_desc.thetext:
After deleting a file outside of Eclipse and refreshing the folder, the file is no longer shown in the navigator view (==> OK). When synchronizing the folder, the deleted file is not remembered as outgoing deletion. Additionally there is no incoming file (==> ERROR).
Eclipse 3.1 automatically has added deleted resources, which were detected from refreshing, to the outgoing changes.
Looks like a dupe of #150483. I've seen this too; turning off "Allow models to participate in synchronizations" seemed to fix it for me.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 150483 ***

bug.short_desc: EL string literals containing quotes

long_desc.thetext:
According to Sun's documentation you can have a quote inside a JSP EL string literal and you have to escape it with a backslash:
> http://java.sun.com/j2ee/1.4/docs/tutorial/doc/JSPIntro7.html > ... > String: with single and double quotes; " is escaped as \", ' is escaped as \', > and \ is escaped as \\. > ...
If you put in a JSP something like: <c:set var="myvar" value="my \"quoted\" val" /> ${myvar} it will execute fine and the string my "quoted" val will be displayed as expected.
The WTP editor however will highlight that code in red and will claim it contains the following errors: - Attribute """ has no value - Attribute "\" has no value
This is imho incorrect as the mentioned code is perfectly valid JSP EL and contains no errors.
maybe duplicate or related to bug 104767?

bug.short_desc: details sash same background color as tree

long_desc.thetext:
With versions 3.1 and below I could resize the lower pane (the detail area) of the inspect popup, when debugging.
I use the Ctrl+Shift+I shortcut for the inspect popup to appear.
Can provide screenshot if necessary.

This works for me on Win XP and Linux. The sash is not pronounced though, if you move the mouse above the text in the details area you no longer get the move sash cursor?
Can you provide a screenshot?
Created an attachment (id=46565) Screenshot showing the problem
Attached a screenshot!

The splitters does exist, but it is invisible.
The only visual feedback of its existence is the change of the mouse pointer.
We thought this was an SWT bug, but turns out to be a background color issue. See bug 127817.
Fixed in InspectPopupDialog.
Fix was to add the sash to the list of controls excluded from the default "info" background color setting. Please verify, Mike.
*** Bug 152268 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
verified

bug.short_desc: alleged syntax error blocks refactor-rename

long_desc.thetext:
Renaming an aspect by Refactor>Rename leads to the message: "This refactoring cannot be performed due to syntax errors in the compilation unit. (...)"
Renaming a pointcut: dito.
I am not sure if renaming an aspect or a pointcut is supported by AJDT. Either the refactoring is blocked, or the message is misleading.
Environment: Eclipse Callisto with AJDT 1.4.0.

This is a known issue. Refactor > Rename causes JDT to try to interpret the aspect as a class. As a workaround there should be "Rename..." action directly on the right-click menu (ie not under the Refactor submenu) which does successfully rename aspects.

bug.short_desc: Add url pattern servlet mapping in http registry / entension

long_desc.thetext:
Like what we did in web.xml, <servlet-mapping> <servlet-name>equinoxbridgeservlet</servlet-name> <url-pattern>/*</url-pattern> </servlet-mapping> we should be able to add url pattern servlet mapping in org.eclipse.equinox.http.registry.servlets extension point.
It will affects the implementation of the methods of HttpServletRequestAdaptor like getServletPath, getPathInfo. This bug is from the integration of Tapestry, which uses getServletPath and getPathInfo as source of page name decoding.

Hi John,
The http.registry maps the OSGi HttpService which does not specify support for wildcards. With that said, the Http Services pattern matching algorithm implicitly has the effect of using a wild-card so...
"/garden/*" in your web.xml should be equivalent to "/garden" when registered with the HttpService in terms of what getServletPath and getPathInfo return.
Does this work for you? If not could you post an example and we can look at doinig something implementation specific.

For my usage, there's no problem in transfering control to my servlet(tapestry ApplicationServlet in my case). Add an extension and put alias (garden), it will transfer control to my servlet. The problem lies in the implementation of the HttpServletRequestAdaptor, methods getServletPath and getPathInfo specifically. When I access "http://..../garden/xxx.xx", in my servlet, when I use the method I get "/garden". But if I'm called directly from the container, the return value is "/garden/xxx.xx". I think the HttpServletRequestAdaptor should act just as the regular container-provided HttpServletRequest. So the pattern mapping may be a new mapping style.

Created an attachment (id=46559) Hello WAR
Hi John, I've been experimenting with this in and am not seeing the container add the "xxx.xx" to the ServletPath as you described. I've tried this in Tom Cat 5.5 and Jetty 6. (Also see pg. 39 of the 2.4 Servlet spec.)
Could you try this super basic WAR on your container to see if you can reproduce.
Is it possible that the ApplicationServlet is doing the mapping and that somehow the process is getting interfered with in another way?

Hi Simon, I'm sorry for the bothering. The mapping I used was <servlet-mapping> <servlet-name>HelloServlet</servlet-name> <url-pattern>*.xxx</url-pattern> </servlet-mapping> not the "/*", but the "*.xxx", "*.html". Only in this case, the getServletPath and getPathInfo works like what I said. In the "/*" case, there is no problem.

Ah... Ok, that's supported on the HEAD. (it's actually handled in org.eclipse.equinox.servlet.bridge.http)
Try "/*.xxx" or "/garden/*.xxx" as your alias. Note: The leading slash is required by the HttpService -- also extension-mappings are namespaced by their prefix so "/*.xxx" and "/garden/*.xxx" are two distinct mappings.
Let me know if that works for you so we can close this.

Thanks. But I couldn't find the changed source codes. I'm using the projects of cvs :pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:/cvsroot/eclipse/ equinox-incubator/org.eclipse.equinox.servlet.*. Am using the correct ones?
Yes. That sounds right. The changes were made in and around June 12th of this year. You can synch to HEAD for those projects as they work fine with 3.2.
Support already available on HEAD
Yes. Fix confirmed. It works.

bug.short_desc: StructuredDocument is not reloaded on ResourceChangedEvent

long_desc.thetext:
StructuredDocument is not reloaded on ResourceChangedEvent
When a structured document has read-only regions, the document cannot be reloaded even on ResourceChangedEvent after the underlying file's modification. The document cannot be reverted, neither.
Majour severity because the conflict between disk and FileBuffer can override some changes.
Observation: Both 'revert' and 'reload' are the same reason. They reach ResourceTextFileBuffer#handleFileContent(), and call Basic(or JobSafe)StructuredDocument#set(String, long). Although BasicStructuredDocument#set(String) ignores read only settings, BasicStructuredDocument#set(String, long) does NOT. And the call of set(String, long) fails because of read-only. So, I think that set(String, long) should also ignore read only settings.

Created an attachment (id=46503) Test case
Please run the action with HTML Editor(or JSP Editor) opened.
Change to major severity as in the initial description.
Created an attachment (id=46791) org.eclipse.wst.sse.core.patch

Created an attachment (id=46792) org.eclipse.wst.xml.ui.tests.patch
Unit test for this bug.
Released changes for both 1.5.1 and head.
closing

bug.short_desc: [Contributions] SubStatusLineManager.setMessage(String) does not work

long_desc.thetext:
The setMessage(String) does not work with the IStatusLineManager returned by getActionBars().getStatusLineManager() on an IViewSite.
The implementation is SubStatusLineManager. Looking at the code, line 115, it seems that this method invokes setMessage(String) on the parent StatusLineManager, which slightly differs from the previous method setErrorMessage(String), which works fine but invokes the setErrorMessage(Image, String) on the parent StatusLineManager, passing null as the image.
Strangely, the setMessage(Image, String) works fine, passing null as image.
I looked a bit further in the code but did not find the cause of this bug.
Workaround: use setMessage(null, yourString).
regards,
Denis Jouvin.
Assigning to component owner PW
Denis, I cannot reproduce this on 3.4M1. Could you try that release or 3.3.0 and let us know if it's still a problem?

bug.short_desc: Provide support for JUnit V4.

long_desc.thetext:
Provide support support for JUnit V4.
As for April 2006, JUnit V4 (http://www.instrumentalservices.com/media/articles/java/junit4/JUnit4.pdf) has been released (http://sourceforge.net/forum/forum.php?forum_id=541181). Currently, Eclipse V3.2 ships JUnit V4.1.0. The TPTP JUnit and JUnit plug-in support should be updated to support JUnit V4 including:
-Updating the TPTP JUnit and JUnit plug-in test wizards to query the user for the version of the imported/generated JUint test. -Updating the TPTP JUnit and JUnit plug-in test editor to support the new structure of JUnit V4 tests. -Updating the TPTP JUnit and JUnit plug-in test generator to generated JUnit V4 test classes. -Updating the TPTP JUnit and JUnit plug-in test runner to run JUnit V4 test classes.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 149307 ***
ACTION: Please update the target to the release AND iteration that this defect was returned/fixed.
ACTION: Please verify/close this defect.
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.

Closing by default since not verified/closed by the originator in the 6+ months since being resolved.
Please reopen if the issue is still present in the latest TPTP release or the resolution is not correct.
Re-opening since duplicate defect is not yet resolved.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 149307 ***
Reopening as root-level enhancement for JUnit 4 support in TPTP.
See http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/cross-project-issues-dev/msg01065.html for JUnit 4 in Eclipse/Europa.
*** Bug 154844 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 149306 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 149307 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Additional requirements:
1) TPTP should be able to import JUnit 4.0 unit tests and to execute them (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149306).
2) TPTP should be able to create using a wizard JUnit 4.0 unit tests, and to execute them (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149307).
Correcting priority since not a 4.5 candidate enhancement (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/bugzilla.html).

bug.short_desc: ECrossReferenceAdapter.resolveAll causes extraneous proxy resolution

long_desc.thetext:
I have run into a problem in using the ECrossReferenceAdapter (via CacheAdapter) in the UML metamodel. I am finding that containment proxies are being resolved (and, hence, resources loaded) when I don't want them to be, and the cause seems to the in the ECrossReferenceAdapter.resolveAll(EObject) method.
Attached is a JUnit test that demonstrates. It creates four resources, all of which have contain exactly one object. One of these resources contains a UML Model that cross-resource-contains three Packages (stored in the other resources). If I load one of the Package resources and perform a reverse-reference query (using the adapter) on the package that it contains, then I find that the other two Package resources are also loaded (depending on the ordering of the list of contained packages).
Also attached is a one-line patch for the ECrossReferenceAdapter.resolveAll(EObject) method that does the indexOf(proxy) search on the basic list view of a list setting, instead of assuming that the list will not resolve proxies in its indexOf() implementation. All of EMF's list implementations do not resolve proxies in the indexOf() except as a last resort, but the DerivedUnionEObjectEList in UML does resolve.

Created an attachment (id=46504) JUnit test and patch
As described in the initial comment, find attached a JUnit test and a patch.
The proposed fix has been committed to CVS.

bug.short_desc: apply button not enabled when rule set is chosen

long_desc.thetext:
When the "set" button is clicked with a specific rule set chosen, the rules are corrcetly selected in the rule tree, but the "apply" button is not enabled. Thus, the rules will not actually be used when you click "analyze."
When the tree is expanded after the rule set has been selected with the "set" button, the "apply" button is suddenly enabled again, and clicking that button causes the rule set to be correctly applied. This is *not* a good work-around though, since it is far from obvious.
The fix looks to be simple -- when the set button is clicked, enable the apply button.
The original report from Harish Dewan follows:
This is related to Java Static analysis rules. When I select any of the java rule sets from the 'Rule Sets' combo box and click on the 'Set' button the corresponding java rules are selected in the 'Rules' tab but
When I analyze the code with the rule set it shows zero results. It shows me proper results only when I expand the tree in 'Rules' tab after rule set selection. Steps for reproducing the problem: 1) In the analysis launch configuration dialog box set 'Java Best Practices' as rule set. The best practices rules get selected in the rules section. 2) Invoke analysis button and there will be zero results. But if we expand the rules tree before step 2 the results are properly generated. In short the rules tree should be clicked or set focused before the analysis is done.
Is this a common behavior or only I am facing the problem?
Thanks & Regards Harish.
The dialog buttons now get updated when a rule set is applied
closed

bug.short_desc: Add support for HTTP Digest authentication to Trac connector

long_desc.thetext: Currently (0.6.0.v20060717-2300), the Trac connector supports only Basic HTTP authentication. Please add support for HTTP Digest authentication.
Currently HttpURLConnection is used to connect to the repository which does not support digest authentication. The implementation needs to be changed to use Apache HTTPClient instead.

Created an attachment (id=46619) mylar/context/zip
To make mylar.tasks.core the place that encapsulates our http/url connections, I extracted our URLConnection code into mylar.internal.tasks.core.UrlConnectionUtil. This will help ensure that we use consistent proxy and ssl connections. You can add the HTTPClient code you need to that class.
Also note that we make considerably use of HttpClient elsewhere in the code (just search for that text), so we amy want to extract some of that to use the common UrlConnectionUtil.
Steffen, what's the eta of this? It seems like it's blocking people given the comments on bug 140512.
The implementation is done. I just need to setup a repository with digest authentication to test it. I'll submit a patch the migration to XML-RPC 3.0 has been merged (bug 151896).
Created an attachment (id=46914) mylar/context/zip

Created an attachment (id=46915) Replaces all uses of URLConnection by HttpClient
I have setup a repository that requires digest authentication at http://mylar.eclipse.org/trac010digest . Some of the Trac test cases now require a credentials.properties file identical to the one used by Bugzilla (this completes part of the work for bug 150456).

Regarding the static initializer on UrlConnectionUtil for the logging initialization of HttpClient (bug 151896 comment #13): This should be called as early as possible otherwise an instance of HttpClient may already have been created and the system properties will be ignored. This is currently the case when running the Trac tests and causes some console output.

Patch applied. I moved the commons initialization to UrlConnectionUtil.initCommonsLogginSettings(), which is now called from TasksUiPlugin.start(..). We could also add a call to that to AllTracTests.suite() in order to avoid the console output, but when I tried that I still got some output values that printed "4" two times.

Created an attachment (id=46920) Remove call to System.out.println()
My bad. Forgot to remove a debug statement.
Patch applied.
Should 0.6.0.v20060727-1630 be able to do digest authentication? It didn't work for me, it still tried to do "basic" authentication. Do I need to explicitly (sp?) configure it to use digest?

(In reply to comment #12) > Should 0.6.0.v20060727-1630 be able to do digest authentication? It didn't work > for me, it still tried to do "basic" authentication. Do I need to explicitly > (sp?) configure it to use digest?
Yes, it should do digest authentication. I think the library tries basic authentication first before attempting digest authentication. There is no special configuration option.
Are you using the "XML-RPC" or "Trac 0.9" mode to access the repository?
Josh: is the authentication working for you?

Got it!
I had "http://server/trac/projectfoo/" as the repository URL. Changing it to "http://server/trac/projectfoo" (no trailing slash) did it.

Mik, thanks for checking back but I was intending to say with my comment from bug #140512 (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=140512#c12) that my browser is currently non-functional, not Mylar related rather AMD64, https, etc. etc. Other bugs to file, perhaps, but I won't be able to test the new build. Again, thanks, and as soon as I have my other issues worked out, I'll get back on the boat.

Daniel: The trailing slash problem is bug 150890 and will hopefully be fixed before the release since others are bound to encounter this problem.
Josh: we have some Linux-specific browser troubleshooting instructions at: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_FAQ#Installing_on_Linux If you could add your problems there that would be great (e.g. indicate that Eclipse's browser won't work on AMD64 with any OS specific details, you could make a new section if not running Linux). That would help others in the same boat as you. Also note that https will be working on Linux in an upcoming release if it isn't already (bug 80033).

bug.short_desc: Team Synchronize not finding new packages in CVS

long_desc.thetext:
After installing a fresh 3.2 and using the old workspace with -data, team->synchronize is broken. 1) Selecting a package fails to find new a sub-package in repository.E.g. I have com.x.y.a, com.x.y.b and a new package com.x.y.c is there. Select synchronize on the com.x.y package says "No changes Found". If I touch the file, do F5 and then Replace with Latest from HEAD it works. 2) Select com.x.y only finds changes in files within com.x.y and does not recurse. I am forced to manually traverse the entire source tree doing synchronize on bottom level packages.
3.1 did not have these problems. cvs is 1.11.2 on Linux RHEL3 and accessed via extssh.
In 3.2, Eclipse swicth to using model based sematics to determine the depth of operations. Java packages are shallow and hence Team operations do not include subpackages.

Can we do something (like a switch) to enable recursion when resynchronising a project with a repository that's had a lot of changes?
It is painful in the extreme to first find and then synchronise them manually.

Why can't you just synchronize the project? Alternatively, if your packages are contained in a source folder, you can synchronize the source folder.
What you can do is switch the sync view to Workspace mode using the dropdown toolbar item that is third from the left and then set that to hierarchy mode in the Sync View preferences.
Thanks - I did not realise the functionality was different depending on the view.

bug.short_desc: TextEdit#toString() should render hierarchy

long_desc.thetext:
I20060718-0800
TextEdit#toString() should render the full hierarchy of edits. Patch follows.

Created an attachment (id=46508) Patch
The patch also fixes outdated javadoc of class TextEdit.

Is your enhancement because current toString wrong? Or, you just want it to be better? For use in some program logic? If so, I'd suggest making a new function, instead of using "toString", as that's typically "for debugging" and seldom "API" in the normal sense of the word. (That is, normally what it returns would not be gaurenteed from one release to another).
Perhaps "mergedText" would be a good name?

Object#toString() is commonly only to be used for debugging purposes (exept if explicitly specified otherwise). The format is unspecified and should only serve the (human) debugger. In this case, I found that showing the children would generally be useful if you need to look at TextEdits. So: - it was not "wrong", just not as useful as it could be - I would never base any program logic on the unspecified result of toString()

Thanks Markus.
Fixed in HEAD with some minor (Java)doc additions and verified that deleting methods which still appear in the hierarchy is a binary compatible change.
Available in builds > N20060719-0010.

bug.short_desc: XPath axis expression not working

long_desc.thetext: I have created a Data Source, and am trying to create a data set. I start by selecting the nodes I want with the XPath query //node-name. I then start adding columns. One column I would like to add is ancestor::parent-node/other-child. I have to use the ancestor:: axis because I don't know how far up the particular parent node I want is. I haven't been able to test other XPath axis expressions as of yet, but I will update with other ones as I can. Thanks.
All axis like ancestor::axis are not supported by XML driver. We will discuss to see if these axis need to be added to the spec and implemented.

Not being able to use predecessor:: also makes finding unique values in an XML document impossible (at least with XPath alone). This would be very handy in creating charts. In my case, I have a list of elements all with various values to a certain attribute. I want a list of those distinct attributes and a count of how many share that value for use in a pie chart.

bug.short_desc: [EditorMgmt] Editor History not updated when SourceLookupFacility reuses an open editor

long_desc.thetext:
When the SourceLookupFacility reuses an already open editor (openEditor method calls setInput), the new IEditiorInput is not added to the workbench's editor history.
If a page.openEditor is called, then the workbench editor history is updated.
Problem can be demonstrated with the JDT. To recreate the problem: Make sure the Run/Debug preferences is set to reuse editors Set a breakpoint somewhere in a Java program (The breakpoint will need to be several calls deep through different classes). Close All Editors (Open and close enough editors on class files you will not be debugging, to fill up the MRU with irrelevant files) Execute the Java program and hit the breakpoint. The file with the breakpoint should be opened automatically. Notice that the file should have been added to the MRU (under the File menu) Now using the Debug View, click back into the stack frame to a method that is in another class. The editor should switch to that class. Check the MRU list. It should not be showing the 2nd class like I think it should.
Basically, SourceLookupFacility.openEditor(...) will call setInput on the editor directly if it is an IReusableEditor and it is already opened. This bypasses the IWorkbenchPage.openEditor call. If the IWorkbenchPage.openEditor call was made, then eventually the workbench's EditorHistory would be modified.
The IWorkbenchPage interface defines a reuseEditor() method that I think should be being called instead.

Using IWorkbenchPage.reuseEditor(...) lead me to this error:
Problem detected with part org.eclipse.debug.ui.sourcelookup.CommonSourceNotFoundEditor (class = org.eclipse.debug.ui.sourcelookup.CommonSourceNotFoundEditor): Editor is not firing a PROP_INPUT event in response to IReusableEditor.setInput(...)
Fixed in SourceLookupFacility and CommonSourceNotFoundEditor.
fixed, pending verification
Punting to Boris
Cannot reproduce. WorkbenchPage.reuseEditor() was changed as part of the fix for bug 165970, which might have fixed the issue described here as well.

bug.short_desc: [EFS] Closed projects on remote filesystem cause unwanted connection attempts

long_desc.thetext:
When a project is located on a remote filesystem (e.g. a WebDAV server) and this project is closed when starting Eclipse, Eclipse will cause cconnection attempts to that remote system. This is especially undesirable if those projects were closed because the remote system was shut down in the first place.
The following is a stacktrace of Eclipse's first attempt to reach a remote system at startup, followed by some clarification.
8 WebDAVFileSystem.getStore(URI) line: 49 7 InternalFileSystemCore.getStore(URI) line: 107 6 EFS.getStore(URI) line: 296 5 FileStoreRoot.toLocalPath(URI) line: 120 4 FileStoreRoot.<init>(URI, IPath) line: 57 3 FileSystemResourceManager.setLocation(IResource, ResourceInfo, URI) line: 806 2 Project.internalSetDescription(IProjectDescription, boolean) line: 663 1 SaveManager.restoreMetaInfo(Project, IProgressMonitor) line: 782 SaveManager.restoreMetaInfo(MultiStatus, IProgressMonitor) line: 746 SaveManager.restore(IProgressMonitor) line: 637 SaveManager.startup(IProgressMonitor) line: 1299 Workspace.startup(IProgressMonitor) line: 1883 Workspace.open(IProgressMonitor) line: 1653 ResourcesPlugin.startup() line: 367 ...
1 SaveManager.restoreMetaInfo(Project, IProgressMonitor) line: 782 A project description is tried to be read; if the project is closed, it cannot be read and a dummy IProjectDescription is created. This description is then set with an internal method (the API method setDescription can only be used on existing open projects).
2 Project.internalSetDescription(IProjectDescription, boolean) line: 663 For some reason Eclipse interprets a closed project as being a resource that has its location changed and so it is set again (to a WebDAV location: webdav://).
3 FileSystemResourceManager.setLocation(IResource, ResourceInfo, URI) line: 806 To set the location, a new FileStoreRoot is created with root URI the URI of the remote project location (webdav://).
4 FileStoreRoot.<init>(URI, IPath) line: 57 The FileStoreRoot constructor tries to find out the local file that corresponds with the given WebDAV URI. If this is not possible, null will be stored (eventually this will happen, but only after the nonreachable remote system has been tried to be contacted).
5 FileStoreRoot.toLocalPath(URI) line: 120 The filesystem corresponding to the URI scheme (webdav) is requested with EFS.
6 EFS.getStore(URI) line: 296 An IFileStore is requested for the given WebDAV URI.
7 InternalFileSystemCore.getStore(URI) line: 107 The IFileSystem corresponding with the scheme of the given URI (webdav) is retrieved (WebDAVFileSystem). This filesystem is asked for an IFileStore representing the given URI.
8 WebDAVFileSystem.getStore(URI) line: 49 An attempt is made to create a WebDAVFileStore that represents the given URI. If it is not possible to create a file store corresponding to the provided URI, a file store belonging to the null file system should be returned. However, in order to know whether it is possible to create a file store, the WebDAV server should be contacted to determine if it responds.
In my opinion, step 3 is the strangest: why must a closed project have its location set?

Thank you for this detailed analysis. One thing to note is that certain IFileSystem/IFileStore methods are "handle only" methods. They can be identified with statements in the javadoc like:
"This is a handle-only method; <blah> is returned regardless of whether this store exists."
As it turns out, IFileSystem.getStore(...) does not have this exact template, but I will fix the doc. Your implementations of these methods should not contact the backing file system. This is quite important, because these methods provide no IProgressMonitor context for reporting progress and/or allowing cancelation. Any operation that connects to a backing file system is potentially long-running.
In any case, there really is no reason to contact the file system for these handle methods - they are really only functional operations on the handle itself. If you fix your WebDAV implementation accordingly, does it still attempt to connect to the backing file system for a closed project? If so, it is certainly a bug that I will address.

Note that we need to compute the location of closed projects to satisfy the contract of IResource.getLocation(), which specifies that the location is computed regardless of whether the resource's project is open or closed. It turns out to be useful in various situations to know where a project is located even when it is closed.

Thank you for your quick and helpful reply; if I postpone the contacting of the server to non-handle-only methods in my implementation of IFileStore, the server is indeed not contacted for closed projects.
I do have one other question: what should the behaviour of the Properties View and Properties Dialog (and maybe other UI elements that request metadata) be for closed projects? These UI elements do force a connection to retrieve information, regardless of whether the project is closed. I assume there has once been some debate as to whether metadata of closed projects may be retrieved. With the coming of generic filesystems, it might be appropriate to restart this debate.

The file system should never be contacted for closed projects. I have fixed the cases in the "Info" properties page, and in the properties view. Please enter bug reports for any other cases you see where the file system is being contact for a closed project.
The file system is contacted for properties of closed projects: bug 152586.

bug.short_desc: [java launching] Add attach-on-demand support to debugger

long_desc.thetext:
From a user interface perspective, the easiest way to attach to a JVM would be to support the new attach-on-demand API in Mustang like JConsole does. It would probably still be necessary to launch the debuggee in some special manner. Still, it should be possible to free the user from needing to manually engage in socket accounting.
Attach on demand http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alanb?entry=another_piece_of_the_tool
The UI it enables for JConsole http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alanb?entry=getting_started_with_jconsole_just
In addition to being an enhancement, this would be a work-around. It is relatively easy to accidentally construct launch conditions that will execute using run, but not debug. This would provide better debug support for those cases.
Not planned for 3.3
The same APIs for attaching a on demand are available in JRockit.

bug.short_desc: Undo after save does not mark server dirty

long_desc.thetext: *** Bug 151111 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I am looking into this defect. At first it seem to not be a problem, but later we discovered that the server that the adopter is trying to use is throwing a event that it is making the object dirty.
This defect is still valid and more investigation needs to be done.

Created an attachment (id=46688) Eclipse patch for this defect
Tim,
I was not able to assign this defect to me, I guess it is because I am not a comitter yet. So, I had to attach the patch for this bug as an attachment. When you get a chance you can commit it.
I modified the "if" statement. The logic was not correct, the point of the "if" statement is to check if the command is undoable. If true, meaning the change can be undone, the server should be marked dirty; if false, the server should be marked not dirty. In addition, for the cases when the canCompletelyUndo return false, it didn't add much value to do a check if there was a next undo event or not(getUndoCommand(src.id) == null). I don't think the list of undo events should be a factor for marking the server dirty or not.

Found a bug in the patch - servers would not be marked non-dirty when undoing initial changes (i.e. before save). The solution I found was to remove canCompletelyUndo (a boolean stating if changes can be undone) and adding undoSaveIndex (a int that stores the last "save state" of the undo stack. By resetting where the save state is in the stack, the undo and redo can set the dirty state that way instead of checking whether the stack is empty.
Released for the next WTP 1.5.1 & 2.0 builds.
Closing.
This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

bug.short_desc: [modulecore] DependencyGraphManager returning circular dependency

long_desc.thetext:
The case I hit was an EAR having a dependency on itself in the following case:
-dynamic web child -EAR includes Jar under EarContent -web child has dependency on Jar under EarContent

Added code to prevent adding self referencing references to the dependency graph.
This is released for the 072706 WTP 1.5.1 build.
have not seen further failures in the dep graph tests in the j2ee dependency unit tests

bug.short_desc: missing class DisplayRenderer in 3.2 distribution

long_desc.thetext:
The class org.eclipse.swt.custom.DisplayRenderer is missing beginning with the 3.2 distribution. We have a plug-in that utilizes that class and in an ideal world, need it made available again.
In a less than ideal world, we need suggestions on where that functionality was moved to.
Thanks.
DisplayRenderer was a internal class. You should not have use it. The functionality was all moved to StyledTextRenderer, but you won't find nothing similar.

closing, I can not put DisplayRenderer back in.
Load the code from SWT 3.1, extract the code you need from DisplayRenderer and put it in a utility class in your own project.

bug.short_desc: J2EE Module Dependencies page fails if manifest does not exist

long_desc.thetext: If the module does not contain an existing manifest.mf file, adding a J2EE module dependancy to a utility module within the same EAR fails. It will add the entry in the .component file, but the manifest will not get created and the J2EE Module Dependency page will not show the utility as selected when you reopen it.
Hi Neeraj - this is exactly what we were just discussing..... missing MANIFEST.
fix is in CVS
I'm assuming that this will be fixed in WTP 1.5.1 but could you please update the target milestone field so we can be sure? Thank you!
Closing.

bug.short_desc: Connections with semantic meaning can be incorrectly reoriented to shapes

long_desc.thetext:
- The SemanticEditPolicy was changed about 6 months ago to return null instead of an unexecutable command if it doesn't find a command. A side effect of this change is that if a client does not support reorienting one of their relationship types, but do not return an unexecutable command in the edithelper (which they never had to before), they would now be able to reorient their connection to a note or anything on the diagram.
- I am attaching a solution that Linda and I have come up with. However, it hasn't quite been fully tested yet and there is one known issue: note attachments can now be reoriented to anything. e.g. you could reorient a note attachment between two classes. I don't know how we would fix this or how it worked before.

Fixed. The GMF SemanticEditPolicy now distinguishes between reference connections and purely notational connections. Reorienting a reference connection will consult the edit helpers for a semantic command. Reorienting notation-only connections (e.g., note attachment) will not consult the edit helpers for a semantic command.

bug.short_desc: ProjectContainerCache

long_desc.thetext:
Create new Corona collaboration component: ProjectContainerCache.
The ProjectContainerCache is responsible for managing the ProjectContainer(s) that are locally known by the Eclipse Workbench. Workbench plug-ins such as ProjectContianerExplorer and ProjectContainerView utilize the ProjectContainerCache to discover and access the ProjectContainers available to the local Eclipse Workbench.
No longer a valid item. Replaced by Context Container Manager Proxy.

bug.short_desc: Create View: ProjectContainerExplorer

long_desc.thetext:
The ProjectContainerExplorer is a special view used to explore ProjectContainers. It provides the user with a set of interactions needed to list/open/close a ProjectContainer.
This view should be modeled after the Package Explorer.
The ProjectContainerExplorer is dependent upon the ProjectContainerCache.
PCX was created. Currently it resides in org.eclipse.corona.container.project.ui
